repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Gas Sector Development Project,
            Sao Paulo Natural Gas Distribution Project, and Hydrocarbon
            Transport and Processing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
All three projects had outcomes that
            were satisfactory or better. The outcome of the Gas Sector
            Development Project (Bolivia-Brazil gas pipeline), was
            highly satisfactory. Sustainability, in all cases, is likely
            or better, though some economic, contractual, and regulatory
            issues continue to constrain faster development of the
            pipeline's potential. The institutional development
            impact of the three projects varied. In the Gas Sector
            Development Project, it was rated high based on the
            substantial sector reform it effected. In the Hydrocarbon
            Transport and Processing Project it was rated substantial
            because reforms were only partially implemented. In the Sao
            Paulo Gas Distribution Project it was rated modest because
            the project did not contribute as much as intended to the
            implementation of a rational gas pricing policy and tariff
            structure in Sao Paulo and in Brazil. Bank and borrower
            performance were rated satisfactory or better in all three
            projects.  Several lessons can be derived from these three
            projects, in particular: Bank involvement in large and
            complex national or cross-border public-private
            infrastructure projects involving a spectrum of political,
            regulatory, financial, environmental, and social risks, can
            bring substantial value added to the country. In complex
            investment projects involving many partners and tight
            schedules, key policy and institutional matters are better
            addressed up front, and sector regulation, in particular
            that related to priority and open access rules to gas
            transportation pipelines, should precede gas supply and
            transportation contracts. Uneven distribution of risks among
            gas producers, buyers, transporters, and distributors has
            perverse effects because resulting risk mitigation
            strategies tend to reinforce vertical integration and
            thereby reduce competition. Clean fuels can be more
            competitive if appropriate environmental standards and
            strong control and enforcement systems exist in the
            consumption markets.  Early preparation of a comprehensive
            and in-depth Environmental Assessment is important to
            influence project design and ensure optimum definition and
            implementation of environmental, social, safety, and health
            measures. Early involvement of civil society in the design,
            implementation, and monitoring of the environmental and
            social mitigation and compensation programs is essential to
            identify all relevant stakeholders and avoid later
            conflicts, and clear participation mechanisms are necessary
            to ensure proper design and successful implementation.
            Involvement of international and local NGOs can positively
            influence the implementation of large and complex projects,
            and help ensure application of the Bank's safeguard
            policies, when combined with Bank and sponsors'
            receptiveness to criticism and willingness to address issues.

2817430.trustfund: TF035270-BRAZIL - GAS SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF035693-BRAZIL - GAS SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Hydrocarbon Transport and
            Processing Plant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hydrocarbon Transport and Processing
            Project 's overall outcome is rated as satisfactory.
            The alternative means of transportation provided by the
            pipelines eased the pressure on roads and ports and helped
            to reduce the cost of fuels. The installation of the Hydro
            treatment Plant helped to reduce the import of low sulfur
            diesel oil and improved the environmental performance of the
            refinery. Key lessons learned are: a) when preparing the
            schedule for the execution of a project, the time for
            congressional approval, if required, should be considered;
            b) to avoid execution delays due to procurement processing,
            during appraisal a complete analysis should be made of the
            internal procedures and procurement practices of the
            borrower, especially when it is a large corporation with
            well established practices and procedures, in order to
            coordinated them with Bank's procurement guidelines; c)
            as energy sector reforms take usually longer than expected,
            the Bank should be ready to extend closing dates beyond the
            usual terms if the benefits of the continued dialogue with
            the authorities override the administrative costs of keeping
            the loan open; and d) the increasing availability of
            project-related information in the Bank's Internet
            pages is highly improving the interface between the Bank and
            its clients.

5079131.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Urban development

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Hydrocarbon Transport and
            Processing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives are to: (a) enhance
            natural gas utilization as a substitute for other sources of
            energy with higher economic and environmental costs; (b)
            reduce the distribution costs of petroleum products by
            substituting pipelines for road and water transport; (c)
            reduce petroleum product losses through processing
            optimization; and (d) reduce environmental costs and safety
            risks in petroleum product transport and refining.  In
            supporting these aims the project includes two components.
            The transport component consists of: (i) a pipeline and
            related facilities to deliver natural gas to Sao Paulo; (ii)
            three pipelines to deliver liquified products more
            economically to distribution centers; (iii) engineering
            design, environmental impact studies, and training in
            pipeline operations and transportation planning.  The
            processing component consists of: (i) a Hydrotreatment Plant
            at the Cubatao refinery; (ii) automation studies focusing on
            optimization of process and centralized control for loading,
            storage and offsite facilities; (iii) an industrial safety
            and environmental program.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Hydrocarbon Transport and
            Processing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives are to: (a) enhance
            natural gas utilization as a substitute for other sources of
            energy with higher economic and environmental costs; (b)
            reduce the distribution costs of petroleum products by
            substituting pipelines for road and water transport; (c)
            reduce petroleum product losses through processing
            optimization; and (d) reduce environmental costs and safety
            risks in petroleum product transport and refining.  In
            supporting these aims the project includes two components.
            The transport component consists of: (i) a pipeline and
            related facilities to deliver natural gas to Sao Paulo; (ii)
            three pipelines to deliver liquified products more
            economically to distribution centers; (iii) engineering
            design, environmental impact studies, and training in
            pipeline operations and transportation planning.  The
            processing component consists of: (i) a Hydrotreatment Plant
            at the Cubatao refinery; (ii) automation studies focusing on
            optimization of process and centralized control for loading,
            storage and offsite facilities; (iii) an industrial safety
            and environmental program.
